q: Eric Schmidt drew fire for responding to a hypothetical question posed at a forum in Washington, D.C., about an implant that would let Google Inc. know what its users were thinking. He responded that Google Inc. 's policy is to get right up to the creepy line and not cross it, and an implant would cross the line. He also said that as users voluntarily share information online, it doesn't need users to type in search queries for the company to tailor the results. "We do

the Prime Minister, his family and his brilliant and dedicated team the very best for what I'm sure will be a long and successful future in Government." Mr David Cameron said in a statement: I am very sorry that Andy Coulson has decided to resign as my Director of Communications, although I understand that the continuing pressures on him and his family mean that he feels compelled to do so. " Andy Coulson has told me that the focus on him was impeding his ability to do his job and was starting to prove a distraction for the Government. Mr David Cameron made clear he had "full confidence" in Mr Andy Coulson and had not pushed him out. He said: "During his time working for me, Andy Coulson has carried out his role with

Eric Schmidt is also keeping for himself the outside-facing parts of CEO-dom which Silicon Vally nerds by their nature are pretty bad at. He has a clumsy way of putting it, but when he talks about the deals, partnerships, customers and broader business relationships, government outreach and technology thought leadership that are increasingly important given Google's global reach, he basically means the large part of the CEO job which involves schmoozing various people in Google's interest. This is an interesting role, in terms of US corporate governance. Non-executive chairmen are common,
